comment._content: this one's misdescribed and mis-tagged.  It's "Ivy day", not "May Day"

comment._content:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163523756/]

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Hi Wystan: thanks for your comment about the date of this image. After taking a closer look, it appears that the image you refer to in your note is from the same event as the above image and this one www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163523756/ which is dated 6/7/11 in the image. The ivy plant under the columns and the woman in the white headband on the left in the back of the crowd appear in all three images. The above image seems to show the class of 1913 holding a banner, standing across from the graduating class of 1911, who are in caps and gowns.

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: An ivy stone or Ivy Day stone is a class memorial stone unveiled at annual Ivy Day celebrations at older colleges in the Northeastern United States. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivy_stone
